On 5 August 2021, Arnault regained the status of the wealthiest man in the world, with his net worth climbing to $198.4 billion. This occurred as sales of LVMH's luxury goods surged in China and other parts of Asia.[75][76] He is listed as "Bernard Arnault & family" on the Forbes Billionaires list.[77] *Forbes* estimated the Bernard Arnault & family fortune to be $158 billion in 2022, positioning him ahead of Bill Gates.[77] In 2022, Arnault changed the legal structure of Agache from a Societas Europaea (SE) to a joint-stock partnership to ensure family control over LVMH in the long term.[78]


Arnault and his family had an estimated peak net worth of US$240.7 billion in April 2023, according to *Forbes.*[79] This made him the richest person in the world at the time, surpassing Elon Musk. Musk would surpass Arnaut in June 2023 in net worth with $240 billion, as Arnault's wealth dropped to $190 billion.

<fragment>

 **Bernard Jean Étienne Arnault** (French: [bɛʁnaʁ ʒɑ̃ etjɛn aʁno]; born 5 March 1949) is a French businessman, investor, and art collector.[1][2] He is the founder, chairman, and CEO of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world's largest luxury goods company.[3] Arnault has an estimated net worth of US$187.6 billion as of October 2023[update], according to Forbes, making him one of the wealthiest people in the world.[4][5]




## Early life[edit]


Bernard Jean Étienne Arnault was born on 5 March 1949 in Roubaix.[6][7] His mother, pianist Marie-Josèphe Savinel, daughter of Étienne Savinel, had a "fascination for Dior". [*citation needed*] His father, manufacturer Jean Léon Arnault, a graduate of École Centrale Paris, owned the civil engineering company Ferret-Savinel.[7] Raised in a "strict Catholic-Auvergne" style by his devoutly Catholic grandmother, Arnault took classical piano lessons as a child and attended elite Catholic schools.[8][9]



## Career[edit]

In 2016, Arnault was paid €7.8 million as the CEO of the LVMH group.[70] In July 2019, Arnault became the second-richest man in the world, with a net worth of $103 billion.[71] Arnault briefly surpassed Jeff Bezos to become the richest person in the world in December 2019,[72] and again for a short time in January 2020.[73] During the COVID-19 pandemic, Arnault saw his wealth shrink by $30 billion as sales of luxury goods plummeted.[74]

<fragment>

In April 1999, Arnault was first considered to be the richest person in fashion, topping Zara's Amancio Ortega.[64] That same year, he set up Pilinvest (Pilinvest Participations and Pilinvest Investissements),[65] a holding company based in Belgium.[66] Through Pilinvest, Arnault has been holding an 81% stake in Agache (former Groupe Arnault), the holding company that owns 48% of LVMH and 63% of its voting rights. In 2008, he established Protectinvest, a private foundation in Belgium set up to safeguard the integrity of the LVMH group until 2023; the foundation locked up the Arnault children’s ability to sell shares in Pilinvest until 2023, by which time Arnault’s youngest child turned 25, an age deemed old enough to assume responsibility for LVMH.[67] In December 2011, six months before Socialist François Hollande took office as President of France, he transferred a 31 percent stake in Groupe Arnault – at the time considered by the newspaper *Libération* worth €6.5 billion – to Pilinvest.[68][69]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Arnault's collection includes works by Picasso, Yves Klein, Henry Moore, and Andy Warhol.[52][53] He was also instrumental in establishing LVMH as a significant patron of art in France.[54] The LVMH Young Fashion Designer was created as an international competition open to students from fine arts schools. Every year, the winner is awarded a grant to support the creation of the designer's label and a year of mentorship.[55][56]


From 1999 to 2003, he owned Phillips de Pury & Company, an art auction house, and bought out the first French auctioneer, Tajan.[57][58] In 2006, Arnault started the building project of the Louis Vuitton Foundation. Dedicated to the creation and contemporary art, the building was designed by the architect Frank Gehry.[59] The Foundation's grand opening at the Jardin d'Acclimatation Paris was held on 20 October 2014.[60]



## Personal life[edit]


### Family[edit]

![An ornate school building](image)Musk graduated from Pretoria Boys High School in South Africa
Musk attended Waterkloof House Preparatory School, Bryanston High School, and Pretoria Boys High School, from where he graduated.[46] Musk was a good but not exceptional student, earning a 61 in Afrikaans and a B on his senior math certification.[47] Musk applied for a Canadian passport through his Canadian-born mother,[48][49] knowing that it would be easier to immigrate to the United States this way.[50] While waiting for his application to be processed, he attended the University of Pretoria for five months.[51]

</fragment>
<fragment>

Musk arrived in Canada in June 1989 and lived with a second cousin in Saskatchewan for a year,[52] working odd jobs at a farm and lumber mill.[53] In 1990, he entered Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario.[54][55] Two years later, he transferred to the University of Pennsylvania (UPenn), where he completed studies for a Bachelor of Arts degree in physics and a Bachelor of Science degree in economics from the Wharton School.[56][57][58][59] Although Musk claims he earned the degrees in 1995, UPenn maintains it awarded them in 1997.[60] He reportedly hosted large, ticketed house parties to help pay for tuition, and wrote a business plan for an electronic book-scanning service similar to Google Books.[61]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Musk was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) in 2018.[544] In 2015, he received an honorary doctorate in engineering and technology from Yale University[545] and IEEE Honorary Membership.[546] Awards for his contributions to the development of the Falcon rockets include the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics George Low Transportation Award in 2008,[547] the Fédération Aéronautique Internationale Gold Space Medal in 2010,[548] and the Royal Aeronautical Society Gold Medal in 2012.[549] *Time* has listed Musk as one of the most influential people in the world on four occasions in 2010,[550] 2013,[551] 2018,[552] and 2021.[553] Musk was selected as *Time*'s "Person of the Year" for 2021. *Time* editor-in-chief Edward Felsenthal wrote that "Person of the Year is a marker of influence, and few individuals have had more influence than Musk on life on Earth, and potentially life off Earth too".[554][555] In February 2022, Musk was elected to the National Academy of Engineering.[556]




</fragment>
</document>
chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Based on the search results, here's information about Elon Musk's education:

Early Education:
- Attended Waterkloof House Preparatory School
- Attended Bryanston High School
- Graduated from Pretoria Boys High School in South Africa
- Was a good but not exceptional student, earning a 61 in Afrikaans and a B in senior math
- Attended University of Pretoria for five months while waiting for his Canadian passport

Higher Education:
1. Queen's University (1990-1992)
- Started his university education at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario in 1990
- Studied there for two years

2. University of Pennsylvania (1992-1997)
- Transferred to UPenn where he completed:
  - Bachelor of Arts degree in physics
  - Bachelor of Science degree in economics from the Wharton School
- While Musk claims he earned the degrees in 1995, UPenn maintains they were awarded in 1997
- To help pay for tuition, he reportedly hosted large, ticketed house parties
- Wrote a business plan for an electronic book-scanning service similar to Google Books

It's worth noting that Musk has also received several honorary academic recognitions later in his career, including:
- Honorary doctorate in engineering and technology from Yale University (2015)
- Election as a Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) in 2018
- Election to the National Academy of Engineering in 2022

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.
